Hi all,

I am working on a GUI test harness that will run GUI tests, unit tests
and http tests. Long story short, the GUI harness helps in building
test suites. Part of this harness is allowing the user to add new
testcases in a graphical tree, define the class name, and the methods
of the class. All of this is embeddable within existing applications,
such as a Swing GUI app to allow a developer to quickly assemble and
execute individual tests without having to drop to the command line.
All of this works presently. My one BIG problem is trying to get the
test results from the test cases that are ran, so that I can embed
something similar to the <junitreport> task that ant has. After a
single test, or a group of tests run, I want my harness to show the
output.

My initial thought was that I did not have to execute a junit TestCase
through the junit run(TestResult) method. Basically, I was hoping I
could somehow get the assertXxx() output directly. As it stands right
now, I use my own custom classloader because the harness allows the
user to specify a location for the source files (which my harness will
auto-generate and maintain), the compiled files, and any 3rd party
libraries the test classes use. I read with interest how junit has its
own custom classloader to reload tests. My harness does the same
thing, only that I do NOT want ANY of the testcase classes or 3rd
party libraries to be on the application classpath. Because of this,
unless I modify/update junit's classloader, I need to use my own
custom classloader. So, all of this works great. I just need a way to
get the output of the testcase runs, and hopefully apply the same html
formatter that the <junitreport> task applies so that I can see the
same type of html pages that it produces.

I would appreciate anyone's thoughts or suggestions on how to make
this work. Worse case, I am forced to "wrap" my test cases into a
Junit testcase/testsuite and execute the run(TestResult) call somehow.
The problem with this is, my harness allows the user to add methods to
a testcase graphically, so I have the name of the method to call using
reflection, but I see no way to directly use the JUnit testcase and
supply the method name to execute. Actually, I take that back, you CAN
call a Test() implementation with the String name of the method. The
problem I have is that I can NOT hard-code the TestCase implementation
class. That TOO is reflective.. right now I dynamically load it using
Class.forName(). So, is there a way, if I can not get the TestResult
without running it through the junit system, to add to a TestSuite a
dynamically created class WITH the method name to execute?

Thanks.. sorry for the long post. Up against a wall on this one. I'll
keep plugging away, but if anyone has ideas, I would be much obliged
to get some help!
